comment_data.body: Hmm it seems like VS Code merges the results as mentioned in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/72679, and it seems like Helix doesn't support this. I don't think that merging the results is a good idea, but perhaps in the future we would need a `filter` argument to this method to allow filtering the request to a specific client.

comment_data.body:
Yes, this method is almost tailor-made for virtual-first operations and multiple cursors. A typical use case is creating cursors on multiple references of a word, then `expand()`, allowing simultaneous modification of multiple words. The controversy in my PR arises from this, as this operation doesn't seem very vim-way.


trivia:
I started working on #31410 because I saw a highly upvoted tweet stating that this method would defeat vim's textobjects

comment_data.body:
why bother with a normal-mode mapping? this is about expanding/shrinking selections, so there is no point in skipping the step where the user hits `v` , right?

Especially if we support `vax`, that's more intuitive/conventional than `grs` or `vgrs`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -90,12 +90,15 @@ BUFFER-LOCAL DEFAULTS
   a custom keymap for `K` exists.
 
 GLOBAL DEFAULTS
-                                          *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *i_CTRL-S*
+                                *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *grs* *grS* *i_CTRL-S*
 These GLOBAL keymaps are created unconditionally when Nvim starts:
 - "grn" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.rename()|
 - "gra" is mapped in Normal and Visual mode to |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()|
 - "grr" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.references()|
 - "gri" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.implementation()|
+- "grs" and "grS" are mapped in Normal and Visual mode to
+  |vim.lsp.buf.selection_range()|, passing parameters "outer" and "inner",
+  respectively

comment_regular_data.body: @ribru17 remember to update the client's capabilities: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ed8f81283e92da0c53ad09068a6de2e0ce1e0ce3/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/protocol.lua#L340

It looks like our ideas overlapped :)

I think the maintainers are not particularly fond of adding incremental selection based on LSP, so I have paused moving forward with it.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31410

Ah, I didn't see that. Unfortunate to see that your PR never materialized. I don't really see the argument against it- seems like e.g. lsp folding is also something that can easily be covered by tree-sitter?

My comment was -- as usual -- about limiting the scope of _this_ PR to be atomic rather than trying to shoehorn in the full stack in one go. So add the handler first, _then_ the UX (which is a broader issue with more surface for input, for better or worse).
Sure. I don't see how much more atomic this PR can be, personally (not sure if you are arguing that it can).

> Sure. I don't see how much more atomic this PR can be, personally (not sure if you are arguing that it can).

Agreed. I think that this is quite minimal and a good first step in supporting the feature.

That being said don't neglect testing ;)
I am just clarifying my comments that were referred to here; I think the comment chain is clear enough so I don't need to repeat myself.

for reference the traditional plugin for this concept was https://github.com/terryma/vim-expand-region

in theory we probably want to make this more of a first-class idea, not LSP-only. Though when LSP is active, it will define the default mappings. (And we just won't define anything for non-LSP, currently.)

The normal way of expanding a visual selection is `a{motion/textobj}` or `i{motion/textobj}`. Can we do that here? We can claim some letter like `x` to be the "expand motion", so in a visual selection, `ax` will expand the selection. And `aX` could shrink it.

> The "grow/shrink selection" mapping is simply sugar on top of that (or whatever the LSP textobject is), in my opinion.

shouldn't we use the same mapping for the lsp case? `van[an,[an,...]]` and `vin...` SGTM
Switched to `an` and `in` keymaps (much better!) and made them Visual mode-only. Ranges are still cleared after leaving Visual mode
